completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument first today in Volvo Trucks North America versus Reeder-Simco GMC. Mr. Englert.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Sixty-six years elapsed between the passage of the Robinson-Patman Act and the judgment of the District Court in this case. In that time, there is no reported instance of a finding of a violation by a seller operating in an industry like this one in which a sale is made to the plaintiff distributor if, and only if, it has already secured a contract for resale to a particular end user. Courts have long understood that mere offers at different prices cannot violate the Act, because it requires two purchases, and that successful purchases in winner-take-all bidding cannot have the requisite effect on competition. To affirm the judgment below would open up new vistas for application of the Robinson-Patman Act where it has never been applied before. This case -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: You concede, though, don't you, Mr. Englert, that the language of the statute covers the conduct here?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Very much the opposite, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, you have a person who's engaged in commerce, who's discriminating in the price that they offer to different purchasers. Now, I know your argument about the structure, but the actual language does seem to encompass the activity.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, I don't agree, with respect, Your Honor. With respect to mere offers, offering a price to different purchasers is not covered by the statutory language. With respect to the sales-to-sales comparisons, there is not the requisite effect of such discrimination -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, just to -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- on competition.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- get to your first point, the statute talks about discrimination in price between different purchasers, and not different actual purchases.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: But this -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: It doesn't seem it's that much of a stretch to cover would-be purchasers, potential purchasers.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, except that, back in 1947, this Court, in the Bruce's Juices case, made clear, in the early days of the Act, that it takes two completed sales to violate the Act. No one sale can violate the Act. Even earlier than that, the Third Circuit, in the Shaw's case, in 1939, laid down that rule, and it's been an accepted rule of Robinson-Patman Act jurisprudence for that entire time. And it is a natural reading of the statute, and in accordance with the general principle, that this statute should be construed consistently with the larger body of antitrust law.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But may I not ask, Isn't it true that each of the parties here, over a long period of time, was a purchaser? I mean, the -- Reeder was a purchaser, was he not? They were a dealer.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: So, they were a purchaser. And were not the other people who purchased from Volvo also purchasers?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Yes. With respect to the sales- -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: So there were -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- -to-sales transactions --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- two purchasers.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, with respect to the sales-to-sales transactions in which there were -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Over a -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- two purchases -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- period of time, you had two purchasers.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Yes. But the statutory language is the effect of "such discrimination" must be to harm competition in one of these justified instances.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: And the discrimination occurred over a period of a couple of years, as I understand it.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor. This case was tried on the basis of several discrete transaction comparisons. It was not tried on the basis of any systematic study of every offer to Reeder and every offer to -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Well, if -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- another -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- these are ordinary automobile dealers who sold out of inventory, would you agree that they were -- you had two purchasers?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Sure.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: So that the whole point of your case is they're negotiated transactions?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: The whole point of the case is the -­ is twofold. Each transaction is one in which there is a purchase if, and only if, there is already a contract for resale, so that when there is an offer compared to a purchase, you don't have two purchases. And when you've already got the contract for resale -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, but -- I mean, you say that, but the title goes to the dealer. The dealer makes the purchase. Aren't you -- as I understand your answer to Justice Stevens, and also your answer to the Chief Justice, if these were automobile dealers that sold some inventory, there would be a cause of action if you extrapolate this -- these kind of facts. One dealer being discriminated against, vis-a-vis another dealer.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: If the requisite effect on competition is shown, yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, and if there was a sale to the other dealer. You would say that there had to be a sale to the other dealer.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: There have to be two sales.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Not just an -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: But there would -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- not just an offer to the other dealer -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- of higher prices.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Yes, but there would be sales if they were selling from inventory. I mean, there would have been a preceding sale, and the sale would have been at differential prices, as between two dealers.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: And that's the typical -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- Robinson-Patman case. That's the case in which there is a potential violation. The case in which there is a sale by the purchaser if, but only if -- I'm sorry, the case in which there is a purchase by the purchaser if, but only if, it already has the sale is the case in which it can't have lost that sale in competition with a favored dealer because of price discrimination, which is what the statutory language requires, which is -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Mr. Englert -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- why the Robinson-Patman Act -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- suppose you had a case of two Volvo dealers, and the scheme is, as this one, specially ordered goods with competitive bidding, but, over a substantial period of time, one dealer -- we'll call that dealer the "favored dealer" -- consistently gets higher concessions, and the other dealer, who ends up being the plaintiff in the case, consistently, in that same period, gets lower concessions. So, we don't have a picture of what you call "mix and match," but two dealers, one consistently getting higher concessions, and one consistently getting lower, and, therefore, missing out on sales or making sales at a very low profit. That, too, would be out of Robinson-Patman, if I understand your view of the statute.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: It -- yes, I think that's correct. That's a closer case to what's the -- what the statute was designed to cover than this case, but, yes, that, too, would be out of Robinson-Patman.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, you go back to the language -­ are you finished with that answer? Go ahead and finish, if you want.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Enough for now, Justice Breyer -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All right.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: In respect to the language, how do you read it? I think it's ambiguous. "To discriminate in price between different purchasers of commodities." Do you read it -- "different purchaser" -- "to discriminate in price in respect to that commodity that is purchased"? Do you read it "to discriminate in price between different purchasers of commodities -- i.e., the commodity, the particular item -- the commodity there refers to the particular item in respect to which there is the discrimination"? How do you want to read it, literally? I just want your -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- literal reading of the statute to -- I agree with you, 60 years, nobody's questioned it. I agree with you, policy reasons, very strongly on your side. I agree with you, at least hypothetically, but for the particular language. So, look at the phrase and read the language as you want me to read it.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, two different issues, Justice Breyer. With respect to the two-purchase rule, if the statutory language is ambiguous, and if it can be read to say "purchaser status is enough," then I think the principle stated in all of this Court's cases, that the Robinson-Patman Act -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: You're giving -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- should be construed -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- me a policy argument. I don't want a policy argument, for the moment. I want to know -- what you're saying is that the word "purchaser" means "purchaser in respect to the particular commodity -- this one that is purchased, there has to be a discrimination in price."

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: And there's a textual reason -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And what you're hearing, I think, is, well, this person, the dealer, bought other items in respect to which there was no discrimination in price. So, he is a purchaser of that commodity. You see, "commodity" could refer to the kind of thing -- Volvo trucks -- or it could refer to the particular thing -- this truck. And I want to know how you read the literal language.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: The textual answer to your question is --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: That's all I want -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- the phrase -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- the textual answer.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- the phrase "the effect of such competition" ties -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Oh, no, no. I'm very -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry, the effect of such -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- sorry. The effect of such competition -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- discrimination.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- was conceded in this case, that there's the effect on the competition. There are two separate things. There is the truck that was purchased by the disfavored dealer. In respect to that, he wasn't hurt, in the sense of the statute, because, even though he got a lower profit margin, that doesn't count. I'm not focusing on that. I am focusing upon the truck that he did not purchase. The reason that the disfavored dealer did not purchase that truck is that he had a rival -- maybe there's only one case of it, but there's at least one -- he had a rival, the favored dealer, who got the purchase. He got the order from the customer, and then ordered the truck. Now, in that one, I take it, the problem is that there was no purchase by the disfavored dealer.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All right. But what you're hearing is, "So what? He was a dealer whose line of business was to purchase Volvo trucks, and, therefore, he is a purchaser of a commodity -- namely, Volvo trucks."

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And there was a discrimination -­ namely, the offer was discriminatory. And there was a harm to competition, in the -- in the Robinson-Patman sense -- his rival got the sale.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, I still question whether -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, I want the textual answer.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Okay. I still question whether the -­ under the text -- the effect of such discrimination was the requisite effect on -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- competition. But -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: The effect of such discrimination is that his next-door rival, in effect, "got the sale." Do you want to say that isn't enough?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Yes, I do want to say that isn't enough. And, Justice Breyer, first of all, I -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Let's assume I don't agree with you about that. Now -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- what?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Mr. Englert, I thought you were relying on the succeeding phrase, where "either or any of the purchases involved in such discrimination are in commerce," which seems to require that -- "to discriminate in price between different purchasers where either or any of the purchases involved in such discrimination" -- I thought that's what you were hanging your hat on, to say that there has to be a discrimination in particular sales.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: I think the statute, read as a whole, compels that conclusion. But if I'm wrong about that, and if there is enough ambiguity to admit of a different conclusion, then the principle comes into play that cases of ambiguity in the Robinson-Patman Act are construed to be more consistent with the overall -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, of course, if we can go back to the language, it's between different purchases of commodities of "like grade and quality." And that seems to me to indicate that Volvo Trucks, generically, must be looked at -- the policy, with reference to Volvo trucks, generically. Suppose one dealer always got a 10 percent discount, the other dealer always got a 20 percent discount over a period of time.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, Your Honor, I think everyone, including the lower courts in this case, agrees that you don't look at the goods generically. You have to look at their characteristics to determine like grade and quality. And I would actually think that the grade -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: It has to be purchase-by-purchase to determine like grade or quality?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Yes. Every Robinson-Patman case there's ever been has been purchase-by-purchase at the level of --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Fine. That's -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- sale from the manufacturer to the dealer.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: You've put your finger right on it. My question is so obvious that you're not giving me an answer. Every case for 60 years has been on your side of it. Those judges, though, were -- must have been reading some language. And how did they interpret that language? That's all I'm asking you. A very literal question. It has nothing to do with policy or anything. And all I want you to do is take the statute and read the language so that it is possible for you to win this case.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: I'm a manufacturer. I'm reading the statute. I have to give a price on a particular deal. I realize I can't discriminate in price between different purchasers of like grade and quality, where the effect of such discrimination may be one of the prohibited effects. I say, "Okay, can I give a different price to one dealer or to another?" Yes, I can, because it says "different purchasers of commodities of like grade and quality." It is a specific instance of a purchase, a specific instance of discrimination. The very words in the statute are what judges have read consistently to compel that result.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: May I ask this question, just to get it in the -- Supposing volvo had a policy of granting everybody a 20 percent concession, and they had -- except Reeder -- and they always granted Reeder just a 15 percent concession, and the -- you had the same sales pattern you have here. Would there be a violation of the Robinson-Patman Act?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Well, again -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Prima facie violation.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: I think the answer is no, Your Honor, although that -- although that would be a closer case -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Even if there -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- than this case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- were dozens and dozens -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: This case was tried on the basis of the same transactions.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- of sales to both.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Yes. Yes. That would be a closer case. But the -- it might fit the policy of the Act, but it's a very poor fit with the words of the statute. And -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Well, it depends on how -- whether you regard the purchase as on a single -- each single transaction as a separate purchase or if you look at a course of dealing and say that, over a period of years, the favored dealer is one purchaser and the disfavored dealer is the other purchaser. Why can't you look at the pattern of dealing by automobile dealers over a period of time?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: That would be the argument in favor of an expansive reading of the language in the hypothetical example to cover that case. But it would not be consistent with the general policies of antitrust law.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: It would be consistent with the literal language, wouldn't it? If you treat it, the purchaser, as a -- as -- look not at just individual transactions, but what they do over a period of years, just like any other -- any ordinary automobile dealer. Two dealers in this market, one in Arlington and one in Bethesda, are both purchasers, even though they may not compete on the same transactions, aren't they?

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: No. The effect of such discrimination has to be to harm competition with the favored purchaser. And if all transactions are hermetically sealed from one another, yes, the buyer might like a better price, but it's not complaining about the effect of such discrimination on competition with the favored purchaser. To put this point in perspective, imagine that Volvo raised its price to every so-called favored purchaser -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But --

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- in this case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: You would agree, in my hypothetical, there's discrimination, but you'd say there's no injury to competition.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: There's no injury to competition that is the effect of such -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Even if you -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- competition with -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- got an expert to -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: -- a favored purchaser that is the effect of such -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- even if you got an expert to come and say, "Well, these two dealers are in the same relevant market, and there's a likelihood that customers go to the favored dealer," that would not be a prima facie -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: Oh, if you have that evidence?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: That there is a likelihood that, in a pattern, customers have gone to the favored dealer? That's -­ that begins to come within the statutory language in a way this case does not.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I understand -­

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: There is no customer testimony, no evidence of diversion to any favored dealer in this case, no evidence that Reeder lost profits because of the price given to any favored dealer, only evidence that if Reeder had gotten a price, it would have -- better price -- it would have made more money. Well, every dealer can show that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I understand your argument that there's no injury or impact in competition for resale of the trucks. What's wrong with looking at the statute as being concerned to protect competition to be the Volvo dealer? In other words, you know, they're competing -- if Volvo's restructuring its approach, they're competing to be the favored dealer, even though they don't compete with other Volvo dealers directly.

completeLines.speaker: ENGLERT
completeLines.speech: The main problem with that interpretation of the statute is, it takes the last phrase of the statute and makes it no longer a limiting phrase. It essentially makes all price discrimination illegal. And this Court said, in Brooke Group, and has said in many other cases, that it is not -- not all price discrimination is made illegal by this statute. It does require the requisite effect on competition. I'd like to reserve the balance of my time.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you. Mr. Hungar.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The fundamental question in this case is whether a plaintiff who did not purchase goods for resale in competition with a favored purchaser can, nonetheless, establish all the elements of a Robinson-Patman Act claim by picking and choosing from among different aspects of unrelated transactions. The position of the United States is -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But how can you say -­

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- that the answer is no.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- that the dealer didn't purchase goods for resale in competition with other Volvo dealers? That's exactly what they do every day, isn't it?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor. When they purchase the goods, they are not in competition with any other Volvo dealer. By definition, they have the sale. And so, if -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Can't they be -­

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: That's the point that I'm making.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- in competition just from -- on a day-to-day basis over the years, over a period of time, trying to get business?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: In a different sense, they may be in competition -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Assuming -­

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- with other -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- they're in the same relevant market, of course.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: In a different sense, yes. But the point is, the price discrimination does not occur when there is any competition. And, therefore, the requirements of the Act are not satisfied.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: You're assuming they're not in competition on a continuing basis, they're only in competition for one isolated transaction after another.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor. The -- they may be, in other senses, and in -- and in seeking other customers, in a -­ in some sense, in competition with other Volvo dealers. But, at the point that the price discrimination occurs, they are not. And, therefore, even in the -- in the -- in the -- well, in any of the examples offered by the Respondents in this case, they don't show price discrimination between competing purchasers, which is what this Court, in the Morton Salt case and in other cases, have indicated the Act was aimed at. And as Mr. Englert indicated, that is why, in the 70 years since the Robinson-Patman Act was enacted, we haven't seen cases like this, because it is understood that the Act has no application in these circumstances, and -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Two -­

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- I would -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- two dealers within 10 miles of each other, customers frequently go to both dealers to check out -- to get the lowest price. Dealer A gets 10 percent discount routinely; Dealer B, 20 percent discount routinely. Over a period of time, would there be a violation of the Robinson-Patman Act?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: And all the same structure as this -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- hypothetical? Well, the answer is no, but only for, I think, one of the several reasons why in this case the answer is no. That is, in your hypothetical they are, in a sense -- and I'm assuming that there might be direct head-to-head competition, but the offers are different -- or affected by the differing differentials. So, there is -- there is competition between the purchasers, and there is discrimination in offers, although not in purchases. So, there is still the two-purchaser requirement which is not satisfied in that circumstance. There is the -- Reeder is not purchasing in -- assuming it loses the sale to the other customer, it's not purchasing in competition with a favored customer, a favored dealer, because it's not purchasing at all.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Just so -­

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: But I would point out that even if the Court is unwilling to go that far in this case, that you don't need to go that far to resolve this case and to reverse the judgment below for the other -- because of the other failings in the plaintiff's case here.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: And the -- and the main failing there is that Volvo Trucks and Reeder-Simco do not compete in the same market for sales of Volvo trucks. Is that a correct statement of the record?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: Well, I don't think I would put it that way. I think, again, they don't compete at the point at which the price -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: For any -­

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- discrimination occurs.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- particular sales.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: Right. Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I see.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: And that's -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- right. Other than -- there are the -- the two examples of what have been called head-to-head competition, in one of which there was clearly no price discrimination, in the other of which our reading of the record is that a reasonable jury could not have found that there was price discrimination. And even if there were price discrimination, that one instance, standing alone, could not support a finding of a Robinson-Patman Act -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why not?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: -- violation.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why not? The -- Hiland -- is that the one?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
completeLines.speech: Because there -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Hiland Dairy?

completeLines.speaker: HUNGAR
